recommended_movies: Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964)
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Airplane! (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rapid-fire parody with absurd gags that land like clockwork—my kind of classic comedy.

simulated_ratings.title: Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pitch-black, razor-sharp satire that turns anxiety into hysterical laughter.

simulated_ratings.title: This Is Spinal Tap (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deadpan mockumentary brilliance skewering egos with effortless wit.

simulated_ratings.title: A Fish Called Wanda (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, character-driven farce that keeps the heist chaos clever.

simulated_ratings.title: The Big Lebowski (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shaggy-dog crime spiral whose offbeat jokes and tone hit my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Groundhog Day (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A witty high-concept loop used to deepen character rather than just repeat gags.

simulated_ratings.title: The Princess Bride (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A nimble fairy-tale comedy that balances charm and snark without getting saccharine.

simulated_ratings.title: Brazil (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dystopian absurdism with biting humor and suffocating bureaucracy I perversely enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: Raising Arizona (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Zany crime-with-a-heart energy that stays clever more than cutesy.

simulated_ratings.title: Withnail & I (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny, booze-soaked despair sharpened by scathing dialogue.

simulated_ratings.title: Tootsie (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp, character-first comedy that actually has something to say.

simulated_ratings.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Conversational, witty romance that earns its warmth without pandering.

simulated_ratings.title: The Apartment (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bitter-sweet corporate satire with perfectly measured laughs and ache.

simulated_ratings.title: Broadcast News (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, talky triangle that prizes brains over gloss and still entertains.

simulated_ratings.title: The Royal Tenenbaums (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Arch, melancholy family comedy whose dry wit hides a bruised heart.

simulated_ratings.title: Galaxy Quest (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Affectionate genre spoof with enough cleverness to rise above fan-service fluff.

simulated_ratings.title: The Truman Show (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: High-concept satire that’s funny, eerie, and surprisingly humane.

simulated_ratings.title: Being John Malkovich (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, surreal comedy that scratches my itch for strange, brainy storytelling.

simulated_ratings.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A heady memory puzzle that blends wit, heartbreak, and sci-fi smarts.

simulated_ratings.title: Fargo (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly comic crime where humor and menace sharpen each other.

simulated_ratings.title: In Bruges (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Profane, funny, and bruised—my favorite kind of criminal hangout.

simulated_ratings.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamlike Hollywood nightmare I admire more than I connect with.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wicker Man (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn folk horror whose eerie rituals stick in the mind.

simulated_ratings.title: The Others (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A moody, restrained ghost story that favors atmosphere over jolts.

simulated_ratings.title: Memento (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever structure that serves the mystery instead of smothering it.

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical, engrossing procedural that lets obsession drive the suspense.

simulated_ratings.title: Donnie Darko (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody teen fable whose weirdness mostly pays off.

simulated_ratings.title: An American Werewolf in London (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pitch-black humor and practical horror that complement each other.

simulated_ratings.title: After Hours (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A nightmare odyssey of urban anxiety that’s right in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Kiss Kiss Bang Bang (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snappy, meta noir caper with barbed humor and playful twists.

simulated_ratings.title: Young Frankenstein (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mel Brooks at his most lovingly precise parody—jokes, performances, and B&W style all click.

simulated_ratings.title: Parasite (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A razor-sharp class satire that balances tension, humor, and dread with unnerving precision.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nice Guys (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snappy, mismatched-detective noir with breezy chemistry and just enough bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Hot Fuzz (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A meticulous genre send-up that’s both thrilling and very funny—my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Shaun of the Dead (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever horror-comedy that marries gags and genuine stakes without tipping into schmaltz.

simulated_ratings.title: Network (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Savage media satire whose fury and laughs still feel disturbingly current.

simulated_ratings.title: Best in Show (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deadpan mockumentary delights—warmly cruel, impeccably cast.

simulated_ratings.title: Waiting for Guffman (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Small-town delusion skewered with affectionate, quotable absurdity.

simulated_ratings.title: Miller's Crossing (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, chilly Coen noir—style, moral rot, and bruised wit.

simulated_ratings.title: Barton Fink (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hollywood nightmare comedy that’s funny, queasy, and bleakly incisive.

simulated_ratings.title: Burn After Reading (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A mean, goofy farce—smartly constructed but a touch glib.

simulated_ratings.title: The Man Who Wasn't There (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber, polished neo-noir whose fatalism and craft pull me in.

simulated_ratings.title: Brick (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: High-school hard-boiled that commits to the bit—inventive and satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: The Long Goodbye (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shaggy, subversive Marlowe riff with dry humor and melancholy.

simulated_ratings.title: In the Loop (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Machine-gun insults and bureaucratic chaos—political comedy at its sharpest.

simulated_ratings.title: The Death of Stalin (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pitch-black power scramble that makes horror hilariously banal.

simulated_ratings.title: Wag the Dog (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cynical, witty media-politics shell game—uncomfortably plausible.

simulated_ratings.title: The Player (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acerbic Hollywood self-own—slick, funny, and cutting.

simulated_ratings.title: The Last Seduction (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sly, acid-tongued neo-noir anchored by a knockout femme fatale.

simulated_ratings.title: The Haunting (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pure atmosphere and suggestion—eerie craftsmanship over cheap shocks.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Look Now (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked, uncanny thriller where mood does the haunting.

simulated_ratings.title: The Innocents (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, ambiguous ghost story that trusts silence and suggestion.

simulated_ratings.title: Adaptation. (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dizzy, self-lacerating meta-comedy that’s right in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lobster (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deadpan dystopian absurdism—bleakly funny and oddly moving.

simulated_ratings.title: Sorry to Bother You (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wild, gonzo satire whose audacity outweighs its rough edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Being There (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, pointed satire that turns naiveté into a mirror for power.

simulated_ratings.title: His Girl Friday (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breakneck wit and crackling chemistry—screwball perfection.

simulated_ratings.title: The Philadelphia Story (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Effortlessly witty, emotionally nimble high-society romance.

simulated_ratings.title: The Guard (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rude, witty Irish crime lark with unexpectedly tender edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Her (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A humane, melancholic sci-fi romance that’s smart without being chilly.

simulated_ratings.title: Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deliciously dark, impeccably dry class-murder farce right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ladykillers (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Macabre Ealing whimsy with a killer premise and droll payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lady Eve (1941)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Screwball seduction as sharp as it is romantic, banter bliss.

simulated_ratings.title: Arsenic and Old Lace (1944)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Zany murder-farce that keeps the laughs brisk and morbid.

simulated_ratings.title: Some Like It Hot (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Effortless, fizzy farce with perfect comic timing and bite.

simulated_ratings.title: The Thin Man (1934)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Boozy, bantery mystery that charms as much as it intrigues.

simulated_ratings.title: Sullivan's Travels (1941)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A witty thesis on comedy's purpose that still lands emotionally.

simulated_ratings.title: Election (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acidic, tightly observed satire that is cruel, hilarious, and unnervingly true.

simulated_ratings.title: Heathers (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Jet-black teen cynicism that earns its vicious laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: To Die For (1995)

simulated_ratings.title: Four Lions (2010)

simulated_ratings.title: The Favourite (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Barbed royal scheming, deadpan cruelty with a bruised heart.

simulated_ratings.title: The Big Short (2015)

simulated_ratings.title: A Serious Man (2009)

simulated_ratings.title: The Hudsucker Proxy (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeously crafted and a little cute, clever but airbrushed.

simulated_ratings.title: Blood Simple (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tight, fatalistic neo-noir where tension and irony coil together.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Snowbound greed spiral that is grim, smart, and compelling.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinatown (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, corrosive noir that tightens like a vise.

simulated_ratings.title: L.A. Confidential (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Polished neo-noir balancing pulp thrills and moral rot.

simulated_ratings.title: The Sting (1973)

simulated_ratings.title: Sexy Beast (2000)

simulated_ratings.title: The Last of Sheila (1973)

simulated_ratings.title: Scream (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meta slasher that is witty without deflating the stakes.

simulated_ratings.title: The Witch (2015)

simulated_ratings.title: The Orphanage (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, compassionate ghost story that prizes atmosphere over jolts.

simulated_ratings.title: Coherence (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brainy, low-budget mind-bender where structure serves suspense.

simulated_ratings.title: The World's End (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Midlife melancholy wrapped in sharp, genre-bending pub chaos.

simulated_ratings.title: Little Shop of Horrors (1986)

simulated_ratings.feeling: Folky, playful odyssey with enough wit and melancholy to sing.
